questions.question: A machine learning engineer notices that the daily number of user registrations follows a Poisson distribution with λ = 50. What is the most appropriate interpretation of this parameter?
options: The maximum number of registrations possible in a day
The average number of registrations expected per day
The minimum number of registrations guaranteed per day
The standard deviation of registrations per day
questions.explanation: In a Poisson distribution, λ (lambda) represents both the mean and variance of the distribution. It indicates the average rate of occurrence of the event (registrations) in the given time period (per day).

questions.question: You're analyzing customer purchase amounts and find they follow a right-skewed distribution. Which measure of central tendency would be most appropriate for reporting typical customer spending, and why?
options: Mean, because it uses all data points
Median, because it's less affected by extreme values
Mode, because it represents the most common value
Any of them, since they're equivalent for all distributions
questions.explanation: In right-skewed distributions, the mean is pulled toward the tail by extreme values, making it higher than the typical value. The median better represents the center of the distribution and typical customer behavior since it's resistant to outliers.

questions.question: A data scientist wants to test whether a new recommendation algorithm improves user engagement. After running an A/B test, they get a p-value of 0.03 with α = 0.05. What should they conclude?
options: The new algorithm is definitely better than the old one
There's a 97% chance the new algorithm is better
There's sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis of no improvement
The result is due to random chance
questions.explanation: A p-value of 0.03 < α = 0.05 means we reject the null hypothesis (no difference). This provides evidence against the null hypothesis, but doesn't prove the alternative is true or give us the probability that it's better.

questions.question: When would you choose a two-tailed test over a one-tailed test in hypothesis testing for an AI model evaluation?
options: When you only care if the new model performs better
When you want to detect any significant difference, regardless of direction
When you have a small sample size
When the data is normally distributed
questions.explanation: A two-tailed test is appropriate when you want to detect differences in either direction (better or worse performance). A one-tailed test is used when you specifically care about improvement in only one direction.

questions.question: A machine learning model's prediction errors follow a normal distribution with mean 0 and standard deviation 2. Approximately what percentage of predictions will have an absolute error greater than 4?
questions.explanation: An absolute error > 4 means errors < -4 or > +4. This is beyond 2 standard deviations from the mean (±4 when σ=2). Using the empirical rule, ~95% of values fall within 2σ, so ~5% fall outside this range.
